text:
Jerusalem, once so full of people,
    is now deserted.
She who was once great among the nations
    now sits alone like a widow.
Once the queen of all the earth,
    she is now a slave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She sobs through the night;
    tears stream down her cheeks.
Among all her lovers,
    there is no one left to comfort her.
All her friends have betrayed her
    and become her enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah has been led away into captivity,
    oppressed with cruel slavery.
She lives among foreign nations
    and has no place of rest.
Her enemies have chased her down,
    and she has nowhere to turn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roads to Jerusalem are in mourning,
    for crowds no longer come to celebrate the festivals.
The city gates are silent,
    her priests groan,
her young women are crying—
    how bitter is her fate!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her oppressors have become her masters,
    and her enemies prosper,
for the Lord has punished Jerusalem
    for her many sins.
Her children have been captured
    and taken away to distant lands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the majesty of beautiful Jerusalem
    has been stripped away.
Her princes are like starving deer
    searching for pasture.
They are too weak to run
    from the pursuing enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the midst of her sadness and wandering,
    Jerusalem remembers her ancient splendor.
But now she has fallen to her enemy,
    and there is no one to help her.
Her enemy struck her down
    and laughed as she fell.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem has sinned greatly,
    so she has been tossed away like a filthy rag.
All who once honored her now despise her,
    for they have seen her stripped naked and humiliated.
All she can do is groan
    and hide her face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She defiled herself with immorality
    and gave no thought to her future.
Now she lies in the gutter
    with no one to lift her out.
“Lord, see my misery,” she cries.
    “The enemy has triumphed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The enemy has plundered her completely,
    taking every precious thing she owns.
She has seen foreigners violate her sacred Temple,
    the place the Lord had forbidden them to enter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her people groan as they search for bread.
    They have sold their treasures for food to stay alive.
“O Lord, look,” she mourns,
    “and see how I am despised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does it mean nothing to you, all you who pass by?
    Look around and see if there is any suffering like mine,
which the Lord brought on me
    when he erupted in fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He has sent fire from heaven that burns in my bones.
    He has placed a trap in my path and turned me back.
He has left me devastated,
    racked with sickness all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He wove my sins into ropes
    to hitch me to a yoke of captivity.
The Lord sapped my strength and turned me over to my enemies;
    I am helpless in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord has treated my mighty men
    with contempt.
At his command a great army has come
    to crush my young warriors.
The Lord has trampled his beloved city
    like grapes are trampled in a winepress.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Jerusalem reaches out for help,
    but no one comforts her.
Regarding his people Israel,
    the Lord has said,
“Let their neighbors be their enemies!
    Let them be thrown away like a filthy rag!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord is right,” Jerusalem says,
    “for I rebelled against him.
Listen, people everywhere;
    look upon my anguish and despair,
for my sons and daughters
    have been taken captive to distant lands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I begged my allies for help,
    but they betrayed me.
My priests and leaders
    starved to death in the city,
even as they searched for food
    to save their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Lord, see my anguish!
    My heart is broken
and my soul despairs,
    for I have rebelled against you.
In the streets the sword kills,
    and at home there is only death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Others heard my groans,
    but no one turned to comfort me.
When my enemies heard about my troubles,
    they were happy to see what you had done.
Oh, bring the day you promised,
    when they will suffer as I have suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look at all their evil deeds, Lord.
    Punish them,
as you have punished me
    for all my sins.
My groans are many,
    and I am sick at heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord in his anger
    has cast a dark shadow over beautiful Jerusalem.
The fairest of Israel’s cities lies in the dust,
    thrown down from the heights of heaven.
In his day of great anger,
    the Lord has shown no mercy even to his Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without mercy the Lord has destroyed
    every home in Israel.
In his anger he has broken down
    the fortress walls of beautiful Jerusalem.
He has brought them to the ground,
    dishonoring the kingdom and its rulers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the strength of Israel
    vanishes beneath his fierce anger.
The Lord has withdrawn his protection
    as the enemy attacks.
He consumes the whole land of Israel
    like a raging fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He bends his bow against his people,
    as though he were their enemy.
His strength is used against them
    to kill their finest youth.
His fury is poured out like fire
    on beautiful Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, the Lord has vanquished Israel
    like an enemy.
He has destroyed her palaces
    and demolished her fortresses.
He has brought unending sorrow and tears
    upon beautiful Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has broken down his Temple
    as though it were merely a garden shelter.
The Lord has blotted out all memory
    of the holy festivals and Sabbath days.
Kings and priests fall together
    before his fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has rejected his own altar;
    he despises his own sanctuary.
He has given Jerusalem’s palaces
    to her enemies.
They shout in the Lord’s Temple
    as though it were a day of celebration.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord was determined
    to destroy the walls of beautiful Jerusalem.
He made careful plans for their destruction,
    then did what he had planned.
Therefore, the ramparts and walls
    have fallen down before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem’s gates have sunk into the ground.
    He has smashed their locks and bars.
Her kings and princes have been exiled to distant lands;
    her law has ceased to exist.
Her prophets receive
    no more visions from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The leaders of beautiful Jerusalem
    sit on the ground in silence.
They are clothed in burlap
    and throw dust on their heads.
The young women of Jerusalem
    hang their heads in shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have cried until the tears no longer come;
    my heart is broken.
My spirit is poured out in agony
    as I see the desperate plight of my people.
Little children and tiny babies
    are fainting and dying in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cry out to their mothers,
    “We need food and drink!”
Their lives ebb away in the streets
    like the life of a warrior wounded in battle.
They gasp for life
    as they collapse in their mothers’ arms.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What can I say about you?
    Who has ever seen such sorrow?
O daughter of Jerusalem,
    to what can I compare your anguish?
O virgin daughter of Zion,
    how can I comfort you?
For your wound is as deep as the sea.
    Who can heal you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your prophets have said
    so many foolish things, false to the core.
They did not save you from exile
    by pointing out your sins.
Instead, they painted false pictures,
    filling you with false hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All who pass by jeer at you.
    They scoff and insult beautiful Jerusalem, saying,
“Is this the city called ‘Most Beautiful in All the World’
    and ‘Joy of All the Earth’?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
All your enemies mock you.
    They scoff and snarl and say,
“We have destroyed her at last!
    We have long waited for this day,
    and it is finally here!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it is the Lord who did just as he planned.
    He has fulfilled the promises of disaster
    he made long ago.
He has destroyed Jerusalem without mercy.
    He has caused her enemies to gloat over her
    and has given them power over her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cry aloud before the Lord,
    O walls of beautiful Jerusalem!
Let your tears flow like a river
    day and night.
Give yourselves no rest;
    give your eyes no relief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise during the night and cry out.
    Pour out your hearts like water to the Lord.
Lift up your hands to him in prayer,
    pleading for your children,
for in every street
    they are faint with hunger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O Lord, think about this!
    Should you treat your own people this way?
Should mothers eat their own children,
    those they once bounced on their knees?
Should priests and prophets be killed
    within the Lord’s Temple?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“See them lying in the streets—
    young and old,
boys and girls,
    killed by the swords of the enemy.
You have killed them in your anger,
    slaughtering them without mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have invited terrors from all around,
    as though you were calling them to a day of feasting.
In the day of the Lord’s anger,
    no one has escaped or survived.
The enemy has killed all the children
    whom I carried and raised.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the one who has seen the afflictions
    that come from the rod of the Lord’s anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has led me into darkness,
    shutting out all light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has turned his hand against me
    again and again, all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made my skin and flesh grow old.
    He has broken my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has besieged and surrounded me
    with anguish and distress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has buried me in a dark place,
    like those long dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has walled me in, and I cannot escape.
    He has bound me in heavy chains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And though I cry and shout,
    he has shut out my prayers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has blocked my way with a high stone wall;
    he has made my road crooked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has hidden like a bear or a lion,
    waiting to attack me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has dragged me off the path and torn me in pieces,
    leaving me helpless and devastated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has drawn his bow
    and made me the target for his arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shot his arrows
    deep into my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My own people laugh at me.
    All day long they sing their mocking songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has filled me with bitterness
    and given me a bitter cup of sorrow to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has made me chew on gravel.
    He has rolled me in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Peace has been stripped away,
    and I have forgotten what prosperity is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry out, “My splendor is gone!
    Everything I had hoped for from the Lord is lost!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The thought of my suffering and homelessness
    is bitter beyond words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will never forget this awful time,
    as I grieve over my loss.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet I still dare to hope
    when I remember this:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The faithful love of the Lord never ends!
    His mercies never cease.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Great is his faithfulness;
    his mercies begin afresh each morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I say to myself, “The Lord is my inheritance;
    therefore, I will hope in him!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is good to those who depend on him,
    to those who search for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So it is good to wait quietly
    for salvation from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And it is good for people to submit at an early age
    to the yoke of his discipline:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them sit alone in silence
    beneath the Lord’s demands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them lie face down in the dust,
    for there may be hope at last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them turn the other cheek to those who strike them
    and accept the insults of their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For no one is abandoned
    by the Lord forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he brings grief, he also shows compassion
    because of the greatness of his unfailing love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he does not enjoy hurting people
    or causing them sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If people crush underfoot
    all the prisoners of the land,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if they deprive others of their rights
    in defiance of the Most High,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if they twist justice in the courts—
    doesn’t the Lord see all these things?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can command things to happen
    without the Lord’s permission?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not the Most High
    send both calamity and good?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then why should we, mere humans, complain
    when we are punished for our sins?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, let us test and examine our ways.
    Let us turn back to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us lift our hearts and hands
    to God in heaven and say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have sinned and rebelled,
    and you have not forgiven us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have engulfed us with your anger, chased us down,
    and slaughtered us without mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have hidden yourself in a cloud
    so our prayers cannot reach you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have discarded us as refuse and garbage
    among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“All our enemies
    have spoken out against us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are filled with fear,
    for we are trapped, devastated, and ruined.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tears stream from my eyes
    because of the destruction of my people!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My tears flow endlessly;
    they will not stop
speaker: Narrator

text:
until the Lord looks down
    from heaven and sees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is breaking
    over the fate of all the women of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies, whom I have never harmed,
    hunted me down like a bird.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They threw me into a pit
    and dropped stones on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The water rose over my head,
    and I cried out, “This is the end!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I called on your name, Lord,
    from deep within the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You heard me when I cried, “Listen to my pleading!
    Hear my cry for help!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, you came when I called;
    you told me, “Do not fear.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, you have come to my defense;
    you have redeemed my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have seen the wrong they have done to me, Lord.
    Be my judge, and prove me right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have seen the vengeful plots
    my enemies have laid against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord, you have heard the vile names they call me.
    You know all about the plans they have made.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies whisper and mutter
    as they plot against me all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at them! Whether they sit or stand,
    I am the object of their mocking songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay them back, Lord,
    for all the evil they have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give them hard and stubborn hearts,
    and then let your curse fall on them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Chase them down in your anger,
    destroying them beneath the Lord’s heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the gold has lost its luster!
    Even the finest gold has become dull.
The sacred gemstones
    lie scattered in the streets!
speaker: Narrator

text:
See how the precious children of Jerusalem,
    worth their weight in fine gold,
are now treated like pots of clay
    made by a common potter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the jackals feed their young,
    but not my people Israel.
They ignore their children’s cries,
    like ostriches in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The parched tongues of their little ones
    stick to the roofs of their mouths in thirst.
The children cry for bread,
    but no one has any to give them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people who once ate the richest foods
    now beg in the streets for anything they can get.
Those who once wore the finest clothes
    now search the garbage dumps for food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The guilt of my people
    is greater than that of Sodom,
where utter disaster struck in a moment
    and no hand offered help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our princes once glowed with health—
    brighter than snow, whiter than milk.
Their faces were as ruddy as rubies,
    their appearance like fine jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now their faces are blacker than soot.
    No one recognizes them in the streets.
Their skin sticks to their bones;
    it is as dry and hard as wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those killed by the sword are better off
    than those who die of hunger.
Starving, they waste away
    for lack of food from the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tenderhearted women
    have cooked their own children.
They have eaten them
    to survive the siege.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now the anger of the Lord is satisfied.
    His fierce anger has been poured out.
He started a fire in Jerusalem
    that burned the city to its foundations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Not a king in all the earth—
    no one in all the world—
would have believed that an enemy
    could march through the gates of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet it happened because of the sins of her prophets
    and the sins of her priests,
who defiled the city
    by shedding innocent blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They wandered blindly
    through the streets,
so defiled by blood
    that no one dared touch them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Get away!” the people shouted at them.
    “You’re defiled! Don’t touch us!”
So they fled to distant lands
    and wandered among foreign nations,
    but none would let them stay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord himself has scattered them,
    and he no longer helps them.
People show no respect for the priests
    and no longer honor the leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We looked in vain for our allies
    to come and save us,
but we were looking to nations
    that could not help us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We couldn’t go into the streets
    without danger to our lives.
Our end was near; our days were numbered.
    We were doomed!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our enemies were swifter than eagles in flight.
    If we fled to the mountains, they found us.
If we hid in the wilderness,
    they were waiting for us there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our king—the Lord’s anointed, the very life of our nation—
    was caught in their snares.
We had thought that his shadow
    would protect us against any nation on earth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are you rejoicing in the land of Uz,
    O people of Edom?
But you, too, must drink from the cup of the Lord’s anger.
    You, too, will be stripped naked in your drunkenness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Lord, remember what has happened to us.
    See how we have been disgraced!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our inheritance has been turned over to strangers,
    our homes to foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are orphaned and fatherless.
    Our mothers are widowed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have to pay for water to drink,
    and even firewood is expensive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who pursue us are at our heels;
    we are exhausted but are given no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We submitted to Egypt and Assyria
    to get enough food to survive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our ancestors sinned, but they have died—
    and we are suffering the punishment they deserved!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Slaves have now become our masters;
    there is no one left to rescue us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We hunt for food at the risk of our lives,
    for violence rules the countryside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The famine has blackened our skin
    as though baked in an oven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our enemies rape the women in Jerusalem
    and the young girls in all the towns of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our princes are being hanged by their thumbs,
    and our elders are treated with contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Young men are led away to work at millstones,
    and boys stagger under heavy loads of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The elders no longer sit in the city gates;
    the young men no longer dance and sing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joy has left our hearts;
    our dancing has turned to mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The garlands have fallen from our heads.
    Weep for us because we have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our hearts are sick and weary,
    and our eyes grow dim with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Jerusalem is empty and desolate,
    a place haunted by jackals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Lord, you remain the same forever!
    Your throne continues from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you continue to forget us?
    Why have you abandoned us for so long?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Restore us, O Lord, and bring us back to you again!
    Give us back the joys we once had!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or have you utterly rejected us?
    Are you angry with us still?
speaker: Narrator
